DOC.HEAD: Crew Abandons Foundering Freighter
Eds: NEW throughout to UPDATE with entire crew evacuated; CORRECTS name of ship to Vulca sted Bulka. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The 28-member crew of a Greek freighter foundering 800 miles northeast of Hawaii fled to the safety of a Coast Guard vessel Saturday, authorities said. The Vulca, with a load of scrap metal bound for South Korea from Los Angeles, was in danger of sinking with water flooding into its forward holds. The cause of the flooding has not been determined. A Coast Guard plane dropped five water pumps to the 600-foot freighter on Friday after the ship radioed a distress call, but none of the pumps were working by Saturday evening because seawater continued flowing into the holds, Chief Petty Officer Dennis Hubbard said. If the water was contained to just the two forward holds, the Vulca had a chance of remaining afloat until a commercial salvage ship arrived Monday to tow it to Honolulu, Hubbard said. The Coast Guard cutter Sassafras, which arrived on scene earlier Saturday, tried to tow the Vulca out of the wind which was blowing the water over the bow, but the effort failed, Hubbard said. The Sassafras, which replaced a commercial tanker that had come to the Vulca's aid, was to stand by the abandoned freighter until it sank or the salvage ship arrived, he said. The Coast Guard previously had erroneously identified the ship as the Bulka.
